narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan
narrative.project_title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Survey + Interview Study on Research Data Management Practices

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer:
The project titled 'NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Survey + Interview Study on Research Data Management Practices' expects to generate a variety of scientific data types, including:
- Survey response data (Likert-scale items, multiple-choice responses, and free-text responses) exported in CSV format.
- Interview data, comprising audio recordings (when collected and permitted), verbatim transcripts, and de-identified transcript versions for sharing.
- Derived datasets such as cleaned survey tables, recoded variables, summary statistics tables, and qualitative coding matrices.
- Analysis outputs including figures/tables, codebooks, and aggregated summaries.
- Software/code, including survey instrument versions, interview guides, coding manuals, and analysis scripts (e.g., Python/R notebooks, qualitative coding exports), along with environment specifications.
- Documentation such as README files, data dictionaries, instrument metadata, recruitment materials, and provenance notes describing processing steps.

The estimated total volume of the data is approximately 1–10 GB, depending on the number of interviews conducted and whether audio recordings are retained. The majority of the storage will be attributed to interview audio files (if collected), while survey data, derived tables, transcripts, and coded datasets will be significantly smaller in size (<500 MB).

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All scientific data generated from this project will be preserved and shared to support transparency, replication, and further research. This includes de-identified survey response data, interview transcripts (when permissible), derived datasets, analysis outputs, software/code, and associated documentation. The rationale behind sharing these data is to contribute to the broader understanding of research data management practices among biomedical researchers and research support professionals, facilitating improvements in data sharing, repositories, metadata standards, and tool development.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible:
- Study protocols outlining the methodology for survey and interview data collection.
- Data collection instruments (survey questions and interview guides).
- Data dictionaries describing variable names, definitions, and formats.
- README files providing an overview of the data, including how they were collected, processed, and how to access them.
- Recruitment materials and informed consent forms.
- Provenance notes detailing data processing steps and transformations.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer:
Specialized tools, software, and code will be necessary to access or manipulate the shared scientific data. These include:
- Statistical analysis software (e.g., R, Python) for working with survey and interview data.
- Qualitative data analysis software (e.g., Atlas.ti, NVivo) for coding and analyzing interview transcripts.
- Version control systems (e.g., Git) for managing changes to code and documentation.
These tools and software can be accessed through their respective websites or repositories, and instructions on how to use them will be provided in the associated documentation.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. Specifically:
- Data will be formatted according to community-accepted standards for survey and interview data (e.g., CSV for survey responses, JSON or XML for structured data).
- Metadata will adhere to established standards such as the Data Documentation Initiative (DDI) for social science data.
- Qualitative coding will follow guidelines from relevant methodologies (e.g., grounded theory, content analysis).

These standards will facilitate the integration of our datasets with other research efforts and enhance their utility for secondary analyses.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in a publicly accessible repository, such as the [National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/) or similar NIH-approved repositories. This ensures that the data are preserved in a secure, long-term environment and made available for access by the broader research community.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: To ensure that the scientific data are findable and identifiable, we will use persistent unique identifiers (e.g., DOIs) and standard indexing tools. Each dataset will be assigned a DOI upon publication in the repository, allowing for easy citation and access. Additionally, metadata will include keywords, descriptions, and other discoverability features to facilitate search and retrieval of the datasets.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available no later than the time of an associated publication or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. Data will remain accessible indefinitely, subject to any restrictions imposed by informed consent agreements or legal requirements. The repository's terms of service will dictate access conditions and any limitations on data reuse.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer:
Several factors may affect the access, distribution, or reuse of the scientific data generated by this project. These include:
- Informed consent agreements that limit the sharing of certain data elements (e.g., identifiable quotes, audio recordings).
- Privacy and confidentiality protections for human research participants, which may necessitate de-identification or restricted access to parts of the dataset.
- Institutional review board (IRB) requirements that dictate how and when data can be shared.

These limitations are justifiable due to the need to protect participant privacy and maintain ethical standards in human subjects research. Detailed information on these considerations will be provided in the consent materials and documented in the project's data management plan.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to certain elements of the scientific data may be controlled, particularly when such control is necessary to protect participant confidentiality or adhere to informed consent agreements. For example, audio recordings of interviews may not be publicly shared unless explicitly permitted by participants and assessed as low-risk for re-identification. In such cases, access will be provided through controlled mechanisms (e.g., vetted researchers applying for access) after approval by the appropriate authorities.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer:
To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants:
- Direct identifiers will not be collected whenever feasible; if necessary for scheduling or incentives, they will be stored separately from study data.
- Free-text responses and interview transcripts will undergo review to remove or redact indirect identifiers.
- Audio files will only be shared publicly with explicit consent and after a risk assessment; otherwise, de-identified transcripts or coded excerpts will be shared.
- Participants will provide informed consent that includes descriptions of what data are collected, how confidentiality is protected, and what de-identified data may be shared.

These measures ensure that the rights and privacy of research participants are respected throughout the project.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer:
Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the Principal Investigator (PI) in collaboration with the research team. The PI will oversee:
- Data collection, processing, and storage practices to ensure adherence to the plan.
- Preparation of datasets for sharing and deposition into the designated repository.
- Responses to requests for access to controlled data elements.

Regular checks (at least biannually) will be conducted to review data management practices, address any issues that arise, and update the plan as necessary. This oversight ensures that the project maintains high standards of data integrity, accessibility, and ethical responsibility throughout its duration and beyond.
